searchDocs.title: Backlog Overview​
searchDocs.content: Displayed Fields: Each backlog item is shown with the following fields: TypeTitleProjectStatusAssigneeStory PointPriority Editable Fields: Type, Title, and Story Point can be added and edited.Read-Only Fields: Project, Status, and Priority are read-only.

searchDocs.title: Backlog Items Count​
searchDocs.content: The number of items in the backlog is displayed next to the backlog section.

searchDocs.title: Sprint Management​
searchDocs.content: Creating Sprints: Click on the "Create Sprint+" button at the bottom of the backlog to create a new sprint.Sprint Display: Once created, sprints appear at the top of the backlog. Multiple sprints are displayed at the top for easy access.Moving Tasks: Tasks can be moved between the backlog and sprints to organize work items according to their priority and readiness.

searchDocs.title: Filtering Work Items​
searchDocs.content: You can filter work items by project or multiple projects to display only relevant items in the backlog.

searchDocs.title: Scenario​
searchDocs.content: You need to organize and manage the backlog for the "Mobile App Development" project, ensuring that tasks are properly prioritized and ready for upcoming sprints.

searchDocs.title: Steps​
searchDocs.content: View Backlog: Access the backlog to see all the items listed with their type, title, project, status, assignee, story point, and priority.Edit Items: Add or edit the type, title, and story point for any backlog items as needed.Create Sprint: Click the "Create Sprint+" button at the bottom of the backlog to create a new sprint named "Sprint 1."Move Tasks to Sprint: Drag and drop relevant tasks from the backlog into "Sprint 1" to prepare them for active work.Filter Work Items: Use the filter option to display only the "Mobile App Development" project work items in the backlog for focused management.Review and Adjust: Periodically review the backlog and sprints, making adjustments to ensure tasks are prioritized correctly and moved to sprints as they become ready.  By effectively managing your project backlog in Zymmr, you can ensure that tasks are organized, prioritized, and ready for your team to work on, leading to better project planning and execution.

searchDocs.title: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
Ordering Backlog Tasks​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: In Zymmr, users can organize and prioritize backlog tasks by manually moving them up or down. This feature allows project managers and team members to order tasks based on their priority and size, ensuring that the most important tasks are addressed first.

searchDocs.title: Lexorank Algorithm​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: To maintain the order of tasks set by users, Zymmr employs the Lexorank algorithm. This algorithm ensures that the assigned order remains consistent even as tasks are added, moved, or reordered. Here is a brief summary of how the Lexorank algorithm works:

searchDocs.title: Lexorank Basics​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Lexorank uses a string-based ranking system where each task is assigned a unique identifier (rank).These ranks are ordered lexicographically, meaning they follow the same ordering rules as words in a dictionary.

searchDocs.title: Maintaining Order​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: When a task is moved up or down in the list, Lexorank adjusts the ranks of the affected tasks to maintain the desired order.The algorithm inserts new ranks between existing ones, ensuring there is always space to accommodate changes without needing to reorder the entire list.

searchDocs.title: Rank Adjustment​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: If two tasks need to switch places, Lexorank recalculates the ranks to position the moved task correctly and updates the surrounding tasks' ranks as necessary.This recalculation happens in a way that minimizes the number of changes required, maintaining efficiency.

searchDocs.title: Consistency​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Lexorank ensures that the order assigned by the user is preserved at all times, regardless of how many tasks are moved or added.This consistency helps project managers and team members rely on the visual order of tasks to represent their priorities accurately.

searchDocs.title: Example Use Case​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr

searchDocs.title: Scenario​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: You are managing a project backlog with tasks of varying priorities and sizes. You need to ensure that high-priority tasks are addressed first and that the order remains consistent even as new tasks are added.

searchDocs.title: Steps​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Ordering Backlog Tasks and Lexorank Algorithm in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Order Tasks: Drag and drop tasks in the backlog to arrange them based on their priority and size.Observe Lexorank: Notice how the tasks' ranks are adjusted automatically to reflect the new order.Add New Task: Insert a new high-priority task into the backlog and move it to the top. Lexorank recalculates the ranks to accommodate the new task without disrupting the existing order.Reorder Tasks: Move a medium-priority task up by two positions. Lexorank updates the ranks of the affected tasks, maintaining the overall order set by you.  By using the Lexorank algorithm, Zymmr ensures that your task order is preserved and consistently reflects your prioritization, making backlog management more reliable and efficient.

searchDocs.title: Steps to Use the Export Feature​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to Export: Go to the "Search across work items" screen. Apply a Filter (Optional): Apply any necessary filters to narrow down the items you want to export.Example filter: Workflow State equals "Open" AND Project equals "Test". Choose Items to Export: Select either the filtered items or all items in the current view. Select Export Format: Choose the format for the export: CSV or Excel. Choose Time Entry Format: Select how you want to export time entries: in minutes or seconds. Select Fields to Export: Choose from the following options: Select All: Includes all fields in the export.Select Mandatory: Includes only mandatory fields, such as Project and Key.Unselect All: Clears all field selections. Export the File: Click on the "Export" button to generate and download the file in the selected format with the chosen fields.

searchDocs.title: Example Use Case​
searchDocs.content: Scenario: You need to export all tasks in the "Development" project that are currently marked as "In Progress" to an Excel file, including the fields: Task Name, Status, Assignee, and Due Date. Steps: Apply Filter: Project equals "Development" AND Status equals "In Progress".Choose Items: Select all filtered items.Select Export Format: Excel.Choose Time Entry Format: Minutes.Select Fields: Select the necessary fields (Task Name, Status, Assignee, Due Date).Export: Click on "Export" to download the file.

searchDocs.title: Example Exported Data Format​
searchDocs.content: Project	project_title	Type	type_title	Logged Time	Remaining Time	Estimate Effortfeeec76784	Zymmr Support	Bug	Bug	NaN	NaN	NaN feeec76784	Zymmr Support	Bug	Bug	NaN	NaN	NaN feeec76784	Zymmr Support	Bug	Bug	NaN	NaN	NaN  By following these steps, you can efficiently use the Export feature in Zymmr to create custom CSV or Excel files of your work items based on your specific criteria and field selection.

searchDocs.title: board_customize
searchDocs.content: board_customize

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: The Search Work Item feature is integrated throughout the Zymmr product, allowing users to quickly find work items using the key or title. This functionality ensures efficient navigation and task management.

searchDocs.title: How to Search for a Work Item​
Access the Search Bar​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to any page within Zymmr where the search bar is available.

searchDocs.title: Enter Search Criteria​
searchDocs.content: Key: Enter the unique key of the work item you are looking for.Title: Enter the title or part of the title of the work item.

searchDocs.title: View Search Results​
searchDocs.content: The search results will display matching work items based on the key or title entered.Click on the desired work item from the search results to view its detailed information.  note The search functionality is available on various pages, ensuring you can search for work items from anywhere within the Zymmr product.Using the work item key provides a precise search result, while using the title allows for broader searches.

searchDocs.title: Changing the Sprint Associated with a Work Item in Zymmr
Method 1: Drag and Drop​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Changing the Sprint Associated with a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Drag and Drop Work Items: Go to the board or list view where you can see all work items and sprints.Drag the work item and drop it into the desired active sprint. Start Sprint: If the sprint is not already started, start the sprint to activate it.

searchDocs.title: Method 2: Using the Work Item Details​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Changing the Sprint Associated with a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Access Work Item Details: Open the work item you want to change the sprint for. Sprint Section: Navigate to the Sprint section under the work item details.Choose the desired sprint from the dropdown menu. View Sprint History: At the bottom of the Sprint section, you can see the history of all sprints the work item has been moved through.

searchDocs.title: Method 3: Using the Options Menu​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Changing the Sprint Associated with a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Open Options Menu: On the right side of the work item screen, click on the three dots (more options). Change Sprint: Select the "Change Sprint" option from the dropdown menu.Choose the desired sprint from the dropdown contents.

searchDocs.title: Example Use Case​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Changing the Sprint Associated with a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Scenario: You need to move a task from the current sprint to a future sprint due to a change in priorities. Steps: Drag and Drop Method: Drag the task from the current sprint and drop it into the future sprint.Work Item Details Method: Open the task, go to the Sprint section, and select the future sprint from the dropdown menu.Options Menu Method: Click on the three dots on the right side of the task screen, choose "Change Sprint," and select the future sprint from the dropdown menu.  By following these steps, you can efficiently change the sprint associated with a work item in Zymmr, ensuring that your tasks are organized according to the latest project priorities.

searchDocs.title: Steps to Configure Columns​
searchDocs.content: Access Configure Columns: Go to the "Search across work items" screen.Click on the three vertical lines icon to open the column configuration menu. Choose Columns: A list of fields from the work item table will be displayed.Select the fields you want to add to the search screen by checking the corresponding checkboxes. View Default Columns: There is an option to view the default columns, which include: TypeTitleStart DateEnd DatePrimary AssigneeStatus Select Mode: My Defaults: Choose a set of fields as your default view. These selections will be saved for your personal use. System Mode: Select this mode to configure columns for all users. A message will be displayed: "You are on System mode. The column changes may affect the users."

searchDocs.title: Example Use Case​
searchDocs.content: Scenario: You want to customize the columns displayed in the "Search across work items" screen to include additional fields like "Priority" and "Estimated Effort." Steps: Access Configure Columns: Click on the three vertical lines icon.Choose Columns: Select "Priority" and "Estimated Effort" by checking the corresponding checkboxes.Select Mode: If you want this view only for yourself, choose "My Defaults."If you want this view for all users, select "System Mode" and acknowledge the message. Save Configuration: Your chosen columns will now be displayed in the search results.  By using the "Configure columns" feature, you can tailor the display of work items to fit your specific needs, enhancing your project management efficiency in Zymmr.

searchDocs.title: Adding a Filter​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to Filters: Go to the section where you want to apply filters (e.g., project list, task board).Choose a Field: Select the field you want to filter by (e.g., Workflow State, Project).Select an Operator: Choose from the available operators: EqualsNot EqualsLikeNot LikeInNot InIS Enter a Value: Input the value for the selected field and operator.Add Multiple Conditions: Repeat steps 2-4 to add more conditions. The conditions are combined by the (AND) operator  Example: Workflow State equals "Open" AND Project equals "Test"

searchDocs.title: Saving a Filter​
searchDocs.content: Set the Filter Conditions: Add the desired filter conditions as described above.Save the Filter: Click on the "Save Filter" button.Enter a name for the filter and save.

searchDocs.title: Clearing a Filter​
searchDocs.content: Clear All Conditions: Click on the "Clear Filter" button to remove all filter conditions.

searchDocs.title: Examples​
searchDocs.content: Filter by Workflow State and Project: Workflow State equals "Open" AND Project equals "Test" Filter by Priority and Start Date: Priority equals "High" AND Start Date is "2024-07-28" Filter by Primary Assignee and Status: Primary Assignee equals "John Doe" AND Status equals "In Progress"

searchDocs.title: Operators Description​
searchDocs.content: Operator	DescriptionEquals	Matches the exact value Not Equals	Does not match the exact value Like	Matches similar values (supports wildcards) Not Like	Does not match similar values In	Matches any value in a given list Not In	Does not match any value in a given list IS	Used for null checks

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: The Active Sprint Board in Zymmr is a visual tool designed to track the progress of work items within an active sprint. It provides a clear view of work items at various stages, aiding effective sprint management.

searchDocs.title: Default Columns on the Active Sprint Board​
searchDocs.content: Open: Displays newly added work items that have not yet started.Approved: Contains work items that have been reviewed and are ready to be worked on.In Progress: Shows work items actively being worked on.Done: Lists completed work items that are ready for review or closure.

searchDocs.title: How to Access the Active Sprint Board​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Active Sprint Board: Go to the Project Backlog page.Use the Active Sprint option on the left to access the Active Sprint Board.

searchDocs.title: How to Use the Active Sprint Board​
Viewing Work Items​
searchDocs.content: View work items in columns labeled Open, Approved, In Progress, and Done.

searchDocs.title: Managing Work Items​
searchDocs.content: Move Work Items: Drag and drop work items between columns to update their status.Create New Work Items: Click the Create button to add work items to the Open column.Update Work Item Status: Drag work items to the appropriate column as they progress.

searchDocs.title: Tracking Progress​
searchDocs.content: Monitor work item flow to assess sprint progress and identify bottlenecks.

searchDocs.title: Customizing Columns​
searchDocs.content: Columns can be customized using the Board Settings option.Access Board Settings by clicking the settings icon on the right (represented by {...}).For more details, refer to the Board Settings Documentation.

searchDocs.title: Customizing Card Items​
searchDocs.content: Customize the items displayed on a card using Board Customize.Access Board Customize by clicking the customization icon on the right (represented by {...}).For more details, refer to the Board Customize Documentation.

searchDocs.title: Workflow Status Definitions​
searchDocs.content: The workflow status definition supports the specification of both the start and end statuses of a workflow. For more information, refer to the Workflow Management Documentation.  Note The columns Open, Approved, In Progress, and Done can be customized to suit your needs.Ensure work items are correctly placed in columns to maintain accurate progress tracking.

searchDocs.title: Limitation​
searchDocs.content: The default columns and their labels cannot be altered without administrative permissions. For specific needs, consult with the system administrator.

searchDocs.title: Key Features of Capacity Planning in Zymmr:​
searchDocs.content: Define Team Member Capacity: Set the capacity for each team member across projects. This allows for a clear understanding of each individual's availability and workload. Overallocation Highlighting: Automatically identify and highlight overallocation of resources. This feature helps in balancing the workload effectively. Capacity Visibility: View the capacity for all team members in one place. This comprehensive overview helps in better planning and management of resources. Filtering Options: Filter capacity information based on various criteria such as User, project, or timeframe. This flexibility allows for targeted analysis and decision-making.

searchDocs.title: Steps for Capacity Planning in Zymmr:​
searchDocs.content: Access Resource Management: Navigate to the Resource Management section in Zymmr from your dashboard. Set Team Member Capacity: Select a team member.Define their capacity for the project(s) by setting the available hours or effort. Monitor Overallocation: Check for any highlighted overallocation in the resource management view.Reallocate tasks or adjust timelines to address overallocation issues. Adjust and Optimize: Based on the capacity data, make necessary adjustments to ensure balanced workloads.Continuously monitor and refine capacity planning to adapt to changes in project scope or team availability.  By utilizing Zymmr's Capacity Planning features, teams can ensure optimal resource utilization, prevent burnout, and enhance overall project efficiency. This proactive approach to capacity management helps in delivering projects on time and within budget.

searchDocs.title: Resource Management
searchDocs.content: Resource Management

searchDocs.title: Key Features​
searchDocs.content: Table Format: Tasks are displayed in a table with the following columns: TitleStatusProgress (%)Start DateEnd DateTags Example: Detailed Overview: This layout offers a detailed overview of each task's status and timeline, facilitating effective project management. Gantt-like Order: Tasks are ordered chronologically, similar to how they would appear in a traditional Gantt chart. This sequential arrangement helps in understanding task dependencies and project progression. Filters: Filters can be applied to customize the view based on criteria such as task status, tags, or assigned team members. This flexibility allows users to focus on specific aspects of the project or team responsibilities.

searchDocs.title: Using Roadmaps​
searchDocs.content: Navigating the Table: Scroll horizontally and vertically to view different tasks and their details. Adjust the zoom or view settings to fit more tasks or focus on specific timeframes. Collaboration: Roadmaps facilitate collaboration by providing a centralized view of project plans. Team members can comment, attach files, or mention others to discuss specific tasks or milestones. Export and Integration: Export roadmaps to share with stakeholders or integrate with other tools for comprehensive project management.

searchDocs.title: Conclusion​
searchDocs.content: Zymmr's roadmap feature combines the clarity of a Gantt chart with the flexibility of table-based task management. It empowers teams to plan effectively, track progress, and adapt to changing project needs.

searchDocs.title: Key Components of Agile Project Management​
searchDocs.content: Iterative Development: Projects are broken down into small, manageable iterations or sprints.Scrum Framework: Utilizes roles such as Scrum Master and Product Owner, and events like Sprint Planning, Daily Stand-ups, Sprint Review, and Retrospective.Collaborative Approach: Emphasis on teamwork, communication, and collaboration between cross-functional teams.Customer Collaboration: Continuous involvement of stakeholders and customers throughout the project lifecycle.Adaptive Planning: Flexibility to adapt to changing requirements and priorities.Continuous Improvement: Iterative feedback loops to enhance product quality and process efficiency.Transparent Metrics: Metrics like velocity and burn-down charts provide visibility into progress and potential issues.

searchDocs.title: Setting up a Scrum Project​
searchDocs.content: Define Project Vision: Establish clear project goals and objectives.Create Product Backlog in Zymmr: Compile a prioritized list of features, enhancements, and fixes as user stories.Form Scrum Team: Select cross-functional team members, including Scrum Master and Product Owner.Sprint Planning in Zymmr: Plan and prioritize tasks for the upcoming sprint based on the product backlog.Daily Stand-ups: Daily meetings to review progress, discuss obstacles, and plan for the day.Sprint Review: Demonstrate completed work to stakeholders and gather feedback.Sprint Retrospective: Reflect on what went well, what could be improved, and actions for the next sprint.Build Metrics in Zymmr: Utilize Zymmr to create and monitor burn-down and burn-up charts.

searchDocs.title: Steps to Manage Project Costs​
searchDocs.content: Choose the Project: Select the project for which you want to manage costs. Access Project Settings: On the right side, click the Project Settings icon.Choose the "Costing" item from the menu. Costing Dashboard: Project Resource Costs: Displays costs in terms of the hourly rate.Pie Chart: Shows the overall budget and the expenses.Expenses Table: Shows expenses in daily, weekly, and monthly views. Adding the Budget: Choose the "Budget" menu.Enter the budget amount and select the corresponding currency. Maintaining Resource Cost: Add a Resource: Select a resource who has been added to the project.Resource Tier Details: Inherited from the resource's profile.Hourly Rate: Enter a different hourly rate if the resource cost is specific to the project. Resource Expenses: Menu Item: Click on "Resource Expenses."Cost Calculation: Shows the cost of resources based on the time expended (timelog * resource cost). Adding Project Expenses: Click on the "Expense" item.Add project expenses and enter the associated costs.

searchDocs.title: Example Use Case​
searchDocs.content: Scenario: You need to manage the costs for the "Website Redesign" project, including resource costs and overall project expenses. Steps: Choose the Project: Select "Website Redesign."Access Project Settings: Click the Project Settings icon and select "Costing."View Dashboard: Check the pie chart for the overall budget and expenses, and review the expenses table in the desired time view (daily, weekly, monthly).Add Budget: Enter the project's budget and select the currency.Manage Resource Costs: Add team members, specify their hourly rates if different from the default, and ensure the resource costs are updated.Review Resource Expenses: Look at the "Resource Expenses" menu to see costs based on time logs.Add Other Expenses: Enter any additional project expenses under the "Expense" item.  By utilizing the project costing feature in Zymmr, you can accurately track and manage your project's financials, ensuring that you stay within budget and have a clear understanding of where your resources are being allocated.

searchDocs.title: Examples of Project Milestones:​
searchDocs.content: Project Kickoff: Initiate the project with a kickoff meeting, outlining project objectives, scope, and roles. This sets the stage for the entire project. Completion of Project Planning: Finalize the project plan, including tasks, timelines, and resource allocation. This milestone ensures that the team is ready to move into the execution phase. Prototype Development: For software or product development projects, completing the prototype is a significant milestone. It allows stakeholders to visualize the end product and provide feedback. User Acceptance Testing (UAT): Successfully completing UAT signifies that the project deliverables meet the user's requirements and expectations. Launch or Go-Live: The official launch or deployment of the project is a major milestone. It marks the completion of the project and the beginning of its operational phase. Client Approval: Obtaining client approval is crucial for projects involving external clients. It indicates that the project has met the client's satisfaction and is ready for closure. Project Review and Lessons Learned: Conducting a project review and documenting lessons learned is a milestone that facilitates continuous improvement for future projects.  [Learn more about using project milestones in zymmr]

searchDocs.title: Key Components of Kanban Project Management​
searchDocs.content: Board in Zymmr: Utilize a Kanban board to visualize the workflow, showing tasks in different stages such as To Do, In Progress, and Done.Continuous Delivery: Focus on delivering small, incremental updates continuously rather than in large batches.Pull System: Team members pull tasks from a backlog or the previous stage when they have capacity, ensuring a balanced workload.Flexible Planning: Adapt to changing priorities and requirements easily, allowing for more flexible and dynamic planning.Continuous Improvement: Regularly review and improve processes through feedback loops and performance metrics.Metrics and Analytics: Use metrics such as cycle time, lead time, and cumulative flow diagrams to gain insights into process efficiency and identify areas for improvement.

searchDocs.title: Setting up a Kanban Project in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: Create Kanban Board in Zymmr: Set up a visual Kanban board in Zymmr with columns representing different stages of the workflow.Add Work Items: Populate the Kanban board with tasks, representing each as a card that moves through stages.Prioritize Tasks: Continuously prioritize tasks based on business value, urgency, and team capacity.Daily Stand-ups: Hold daily meetings to review progress, discuss challenges, and coordinate efforts.Monitor Flow: Regularly track and analyze the flow of tasks using Zymmr’s built-in metrics and analytics.Review and Adapt: Conduct periodic reviews to identify bottlenecks, gather feedback, and implement improvements.

searchDocs.title: Utilizing Kanban Metrics in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: Cycle Time: Measure the time taken for a task to move from start to completion.Lead Time: Track the total time from when a task is requested to when it is delivered.Cumulative Flow Diagram: Visualize the number of tasks in each stage over time to identify bottlenecks and workflow efficiency.Throughput: Measure the number of tasks completed in a given time period to gauge team productivity.  By following these steps, you can effectively set up and manage a Kanban project in Zymmr, ensuring a streamlined and efficient workflow.

searchDocs.title: Navigate to Project Settings​
searchDocs.content: Go to the project listing page where all projects assigned to you are listed.Choose the project by selecting the project.Click on "Project Settings."

searchDocs.title: Add Members​
searchDocs.content: In the Project Settings page, choose the icon labeled "People" to add members to the project.Select the desired role from the dropdown list.Then, select the user from the dropdown list. Note: Both Role and User should be predefined. Refer to the documentation for Create Roles and Create Users in the settings for more information.

searchDocs.title: Important Notes​
searchDocs.content: Ensure roles and users are predefined before attempting to add members to a project.Review the selected role and user to ensure correct assignments.

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: Board Settings allow you to customize and configure the Active Sprint Board to fit your project management needs. This includes setting up columns, filters, and swimlanes to organize work items effectively.

searchDocs.title: Accessing Board Settings​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to Board Settings: Go to the Active Sprint Board.Click the settings icon on the right (represented by {...}) to access the Board Settings.

searchDocs.title: Board Title​
searchDocs.content: Set or change the title of the board to reflect its purpose or scope.

searchDocs.title: Filter Options​
searchDocs.content: Projects or Work Items: Choose which projects or work items are visible on the board. This helps in focusing on specific projects or work items.

searchDocs.title: Board Columns​
searchDocs.content: Select Columns: Choose the columns that will appear on the board. Default columns include Open, In Progress, and Done, but you can customize these to match your workflow.Column Statuses: Define which statuses fall under each column. This helps in visualizing the progress of work items.

searchDocs.title: Swimlanes​
searchDocs.content: Assign Swimlanes: Configure swimlanes to categorize work items based on attributes such as: Assigned To: Group work items by the team member responsible.Project: Organize work items by project.Priority: Arrange work items based on their priority level.Work Item Type: Sort work items by their type (e.g., bug, feature, task).

searchDocs.title: Saving and Applying Settings​
searchDocs.content: Save Changes: After making the desired configurations, click the Save button to apply the changes to the Active Sprint Board. Review Updates: Review the board to ensure that it reflects the updated settings and meets your project management needs.  Note Customizing Board Settings helps tailor the board to your project’s requirements and improves work item management efficiency. For detailed steps on how to use Board Customize to adjust card items, refer to the Board Customize Documentation.

searchDocs.title: Limitation​
searchDocs.content: Some advanced settings may require administrative permissions. Consult with your system administrator if you need additional configuration options.

searchDocs.title: 1. Accessing the Projects Tab​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Projects tab, which displays all projects assigned to you.

searchDocs.title: 2. Initiating Project Creation​
searchDocs.content: Locate and click on the Create Project button.

searchDocs.title: 3. Choosing Project Type​
searchDocs.content: You will be prompted to choose between Scrum or Kanban. Select the appropriate option based on your project's needs.

searchDocs.title: 4. Entering Project Details​
searchDocs.content: A window will open where you can enter the project title. The project type will be automatically set to Scrum (if Scrum was chosen in the previous step).

searchDocs.title: 5. Setting Up Scrum Details​
searchDocs.content: Fill in additional details such as:  Project Description: A brief overview of the project.Start Date: The date when the project is expected to begin.End Date: The date when the project is expected to be completed.Project Lead: The person responsible for overseeing the project.Category: Select the relevant category (e.g., Produce or Support).  After filling in all the required information, you can save the project, and it will be added to your projects list in Zymmr.

searchDocs.title: 1. Navigate to the Project Dashboard​
searchDocs.content: Go to your project's main dashboard in Zymmr.

searchDocs.title: 2. Access the Project Backlog​
searchDocs.content: Go to the projects view and click on the project name to open the project details page.Click on the Backlog tab to open the backlog view.

searchDocs.title: 3. Create a New Sprint​
searchDocs.content: In the backlog page, click on Create Sprint.A popup will appear where you can enter the sprint title, start date, and end date.

searchDocs.title: 4. Add Work Items to the Sprint​
searchDocs.content: Add work items to the sprint by dragging them from the backlog.

searchDocs.title: 5. Finalize the Sprint​
searchDocs.content: Click Start Sprint to begin the sprint.

searchDocs.title: So what is a Zymmr project?​
searchDocs.content: A project is a container that groups different workItems together. This group of workItems could cover either a single day’s work or task that will take your team months to complete.  Now we have read about project is all about group of workItems, so what these workItems are?  WorkItem is typically a unit of work, task, bug report, user story, or any other trackable item that represents a piece of work to be completed or managed within a project. workItems are at the core of Zymmr's project management and workItem tracking capabilities.  They help teams plan, track, collaborate, and report on work items throughout the project lifecycle.

searchDocs.title: Accessing Project in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: Accessing Projects: After logging in as an end user, you will be taken to projects pageIf you are not on project page then you can find your projects in the top navigation bar.Click on the "Projects" tab to see a list of available projects.You can also scroll through the list or use the search function to find a specific project. Navigating to a Project: Once you've found the project you want to work on, click on it.This action will take you to the project's backlog page.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0PlOK9DlTUo

searchDocs.title: Working On WorkItems in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: In Zymmr, there are various ways to access work items. For instance, you can find them in the project backlog list, which is available for both Kanban and Scrum projects.  If you're working on a Scrum project, you might also have work items within sprints. Additionally, you have the option to perform a direct search from the top navigation bar.  After you've identified the specific work item you want to focus on, simply click on its work item key, and this action will open up the detailed work item page.

searchDocs.title: Updating fields​
searchDocs.content: In Zymmr, users have the flexibility to update work item fields directly, which means that any changes made to a field's value will automatically save that specific field without the need for manual saving.  Zymmr offers more than 32 standard fields which covers almost any use-case for managing projects which mainly includes assignments, Estimates, Timelines, WorkItem Tracking and others to capture essential information    Explore each field in detail here

searchDocs.title: Adding comment​
searchDocs.content: Comments are simple text based updates to let team know what's happening on the WorkItem  tip Comment supports mentioning teammates so if you want someone to know about a comment, you can mention them in it. Type @ followed by their name, then choose the right person from the list. The person you mention will be notified about your comment and can quickly jump to the WorkItem to see the updates.  Here how you can add comment on Zymmr WorkItem  Begin by opening the work item.Locate the comments tab at the bottom of the screen.Type your comment in the provided field.Finally, click on the "Post" button to submit your comment.

searchDocs.title: Adding WorkLog to WorkItem​
searchDocs.content: Go to the specific WorkItem you want to add a workog for.click on the "More" option, ****Located at the top-right corner of the WorkItem.From the dropdown menu that appears when you click "More," select Add Time LogIn the "Add Time Log" dialog box, provide the following information: Work Type: Select the type of work forex: Development, Testing, Meetting, R&D etc.Date Started: Select the date and time when you started working on the WorkItem.Time Spent: Enter the amount of time you've spent on the WorkItemComment: Add any comments or notes regarding your work. Once you've filled in the necessary information, click the Add button to save the worklog.  Your worklog is now added to the WorkItem, and it will display the date, time spent, and any comments you provided. This helps in tracking and documenting work performed on the WorkItem in Zymmr.

searchDocs.title: WorkItem workflow in Zymmr​
searchDocs.content: Workflow is like a recipe that guides you through the steps to get something done  In Zymmr, Workflows of any WorkItem is managed through states and actions aka transitions  At the very minimum, you will have a Work Item that goes through 3-4 states, such as New, In Progress, Done, and, in some cases, On Hold.    Where can I see this guided states in zymmr WorkItem?  In the Zymmr WorkItem context, we refer to this field as 'Status,' where you will be shown the next states along the transition it go through.

searchDocs.title: Navigate to Project Settings​
searchDocs.content: Go to the project listing page where all projects assigned to you are listed.Choose the project by selecting the project.Click on "Project Settings."

searchDocs.title: Assign Permissions​
searchDocs.content: In the Project Settings page, locate the permissions section. The functions are listed on the left and the roles are listed on the right.

searchDocs.title: Add Role to a Function​
searchDocs.content: To add a new role to a function, press the "+" icon next to the desired function.Choose the role you want to assign from the dropdown list.

searchDocs.title: Select Functions​
searchDocs.content: Available functions you can assign roles to include:  Browse ProjectAdminister ProjectCreate Work ItemAdd AttachmentDelete AttachmentAdd CommentEdit CommentDelete CommentView CommentView AttachmentAdd TimelogView TimelogDelete TimelogEdit Work ItemManage SprintDelete Work Item

searchDocs.title: Important Notes​
searchDocs.content: Ensure roles are predefined before attempting to assign permissions.Review the selected functions to ensure the role has the appropriate permissions.

searchDocs.title: What is a Milestone?​
searchDocs.content: A milestone is a significant event or a marker in a project timeline that signifies the completion of a major phase or work item. In Zymmr, milestones are defined at a project level and help in tracking progress, ensuring that the project is on schedule. They can be associated with specific work items.

searchDocs.title: How to Create a Milestone in Zymmr​
Navigate to Project Configuration Settings​
searchDocs.content: From the Projects listing, search for the project you want to configure.Click on the project to open it.On the right side, click on the 'Project Configuration Settings' icon.

searchDocs.title: Choose Milestone​
searchDocs.content: In the configuration settings, look for the Milestone section. The icon is represented by four horizontal lines.Click on the Milestone section to open it.

searchDocs.title: Create a Milestone​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Create Milestone' icon.Fill in the following details: Milestone Name: Enter a descriptive name for the milestone.Milestone Type: Select the type of milestone (Engineering or Billing).Owner: Assign a user responsible for the milestone.Status: Set the status of the milestone (In Progress, Completed).From Date: Define the start date of the milestone.To Date: Define the end date of the milestone. Click 'Save' to create the milestone.

searchDocs.title: How to Search and Edit a Milestone​
Search for a Milestone​
searchDocs.content: In the Milestone section of the Project Configuration Settings, use the search bar to find the milestone you want to edit.

searchDocs.title: Edit Milestone Details​
searchDocs.content: Click on the milestone from the search results.Update the necessary details such as Milestone Name, Type, Owner, Status, From Date, and To Date.Click 'Save' to apply the changes.

searchDocs.title: Search for the Milestone​
searchDocs.content: Use the search function in the Milestone section to find the milestone you wish to delete.

searchDocs.title: Delete the Milestone​
searchDocs.content: Select the milestone from the search results.Click on the 'Delete' icon.Confirm the deletion when prompted.  By following these steps, you can effectively manage milestones in Zymmr, ensuring that your project timelines are well-organized and transparent.

searchDocs.title: Limitation​
searchDocs.content: Currently, milestones are not visible across the Gantt chart to provide a clear visual representation of project timelines.

searchDocs.title: Project Settings
searchDocs.content: Project Settings

searchDocs.title: Project Listing Page​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the project listing page where all projects assigned to you are listed.Choose the project by selecting the project.

searchDocs.title: Open Project Details​
searchDocs.content: The project details include the following information:  LeadTimelineWork Item Type SchemeWorkflow Scheme

searchDocs.title: Edit Project Settings​
searchDocs.content: Click on "Project Settings."The following fields will be shown for editing: NameStart DateEnd DateDescriptionPermission SchemeStatusCategory

searchDocs.title: Edit Details​
searchDocs.content: Click "Edit Details" to modify the above fields. Note: The project key cannot be edited.

searchDocs.title: Important Notes​
searchDocs.content: Ensure you have the necessary permissions to edit project settings.Review all changes before saving to avoid any misconfigurations.

searchDocs.title: Top Line Metrics​
searchDocs.content: Team Size: Displays the number of team members working on the project. Delayed Tasks: Shows the number of tasks that are behind schedule. Effort Variance: Indicates the difference between estimated and actual efforts. Schedule Variance: Displays the difference between planned and actual schedule.

searchDocs.title: Milestone Progress and Overall Progress​
searchDocs.content: Milestone Progress: Milestone Name: Name of the milestone.Milestone Owner: Person responsible for the milestone.Due Date: Deadline for the milestone.Status: Current status of the milestone.Tasks: List of tasks associated with the milestone. This section is accompanied by a pie chart that shows the overall count of work items in various states (e.g., Open, In Progress, Completed). Overall Progress: Overall Efforts by Functional and Non-Functional Areas: A pie chart displaying the distribution of efforts between functional and non-functional areas.

searchDocs.title: Blockers​
searchDocs.content: Blockers Table: Lists key blockers affecting the project with the following columns: Key: Identifier for the blocker.Assignee: Person responsible for resolving the blocker.Due Date: Deadline for resolving the blocker.Status: Current status of the blocker.Due Since: How long the blocker has been due.

searchDocs.title: Current Limitations and Future Developments​
searchDocs.content: The dashboard is currently not customizable.An overall Project Health indicator is under development.

searchDocs.title: Example Use Case​
searchDocs.content: Scenario: You need to review the "Mobile App Development" project to ensure it is on track and identify any potential delays or issues. Steps: View Top Line Metrics: Check the Team Size, Delayed Tasks, Effort Variance, and Schedule Variance for a quick overview of the project's status.Analyze Milestone Progress: Look at the Milestone Progress section to see the status of key milestones, their owners, due dates, and associated tasks. Review the pie chart for the overall count of work items in various states.Review Overall Progress: Examine the pie chart showing the distribution of efforts between functional and non-functional areas.Check Blockers: Go through the Blockers table to identify any critical issues that need immediate attention, including their key, assignee, due date, status, and how long they have been due.  By using the Project Insights dashboard, you can effectively monitor your project's progress, manage resources, and address any issues promptly to keep your project on track.

searchDocs.title: Key Features of Zymmr Velocity Charts​
Choice of Metrics​
searchDocs.content: Teams can track velocity using story points or effort (hours or days), providing flexibility based on their preferred method of estimation.

searchDocs.title: Sprint Performance​
searchDocs.content: The chart displays the completed work for each sprint, showing both the planned (committed) and actual values, allowing teams to compare their estimates with actual performance.

searchDocs.title: Trend Analysis​
searchDocs.content: The velocity chart helps identify trends in team performance over time, highlighting patterns such as consistent delivery rates or fluctuations in productivity.

searchDocs.title: Forecasting​
searchDocs.content: By analyzing past sprints' velocity, teams can better predict future performance and plan the amount of work they can realistically commit to in upcoming sprints.

searchDocs.title: How to Access and Use Velocity Charts in Zymmr​
Accessing the Velocity Chart​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Projects tab.Select the specific project you want to track.In the project's menu, located to the left of the backlog page, click on the Velocity Chart option.

searchDocs.title: Configuring the Chart​
searchDocs.content: Choose whether to display the chart in story points or effort.The chart will automatically update to reflect your chosen metric.

searchDocs.title: Interpreting the Chart​
searchDocs.content: Planned vs. Actual: Compare the planned (committed) work for each sprint with the actual completed work. This comparison helps in assessing the accuracy of sprint planning.Trend Line: Look for trends in the velocity to understand whether the team's productivity is increasing, decreasing, or remaining stable over time.Capacity Planning: Use the average velocity to inform how much work to plan for future sprints, ensuring more accurate and achievable sprint goals.

searchDocs.title: Adjusting and Analyzing​
searchDocs.content: Filter the chart by specific criteria, such as team members or custom date ranges, for a more detailed analysis.Use the chart to identify bottlenecks, improve sprint planning, and enhance team performance based on historical data.

searchDocs.title: Benefits of Using Velocity Charts​
searchDocs.content: Transparency: Provides a clear visual representation of team performance over multiple sprints.Improved Planning: Helps teams make informed decisions about the amount of work to commit to in future sprints based on historical performance.Performance Insights: Identifies trends and patterns in productivity, aiding in process improvements and capacity adjustments.Team Motivation: Visual progress and consistent velocity can boost team morale by showcasing their achievements and growth over time.  By leveraging velocity charts in Zymmr, Agile teams can gain better insights into their performance, make more accurate sprint plans, and continuously improve their workflow for greater efficiency and productivity.

searchDocs.title: What is a Module?​
searchDocs.content: A module in Zymmr is a logical grouping of related work items or functionalities within a project. It helps in organizing work and managing specific areas of a project more efficiently. Modules allow teams to focus on distinct sections of a project, making tracking and managing different components easier.

searchDocs.title: How to Create a Module in Zymmr​
Navigate to Project Listing Page​
searchDocs.content: From the Projects listing, search for the project you want to configure.Click on the project to open it.On the right side, click on the 'Project Configuration Settings' icon.

searchDocs.title: Access the Module Section​
searchDocs.content: In the configuration settings, look for the Module section.Click on the Module section to open it.

searchDocs.title: Create a Module​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Create Module' icon.Fill in the following details: Module Name: Enter a descriptive name for the module.Module Description: Provide a detailed description of the module.Module Lead: Assign a user responsible for the module. Click the 'Save' button to save the details.Once saved, the module and its attributes get listed. Refer to Linking a Module to a Work Item for more details.

searchDocs.title: View and Manage Modules​
searchDocs.content: All modules available for the project will be listed.Against each module, you will see the 'Edit' and 'Delete' icons. Note: If a module is linked to a work item, the module cannot be edited or deleted.

searchDocs.title: Limitation​
searchDocs.content: Currently, they are not visible across the Gantt chart to provide a visual representation of Modules.

searchDocs.title: sidebar_position: 1​
searchDocs.content: Smart Features

searchDocs.title: Timesheet
searchDocs.content: Timesheet

searchDocs.title: Key Features of Zymmr Burnup Charts​
Choice of Metrics​
searchDocs.content: Story Points: Ideal for teams estimating work in story points.Effort: Suitable for teams tracking progress in hours or days.

searchDocs.title: Three Key Lines​
searchDocs.content: Scope Line: Represents the total amount of work planned for the project. Changes in this line indicate scope adjustments.Guideline: Acts as a reference line to help visualize if the team is on track to meet their goals within the timeline.Work Done Line: Shows the cumulative amount of work completed over time. This line should ideally rise steadily and align with the guideline.

searchDocs.title: How to Access and Use Burnup Charts in Zymmr​
Accessing the Burnup Chart​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Projects tab.Select the specific project you want to track.In the project's menu, located to the left of the backlog page, click on the Burnup Chart option.

searchDocs.title: Configuring the Chart​
searchDocs.content: Choose whether to display the chart in story points or effort.The chart will update to reflect your chosen metric.

searchDocs.title: Interpreting the Lines​
searchDocs.content: Scope Line: Monitor this for changes in the project's total workload. Any upward movement indicates additional work.Guideline: Use this to gauge if your team is progressing at a rate that will allow for on-time project completion.Work Done Line: Track this line to see the amount of completed work. Ideally, it should follow the guideline closely.

searchDocs.title: Adjusting and Analyzing​
searchDocs.content: Filter the chart by specific criteria, such as sprints, teams, or custom date ranges, for detailed analysis.Use the chart to identify trends, potential delays, or areas where scope changes are impacting progress.

searchDocs.title: Benefits of Using Burnup Charts​
searchDocs.content: Transparency: Provides clear visibility into how much work has been done and how much remains.Forecasting: Helps predict if the project will be completed on time by comparing the work done to the guideline.Scope Management: Easily identify and manage scope changes and their impact on the project timeline.Motivation: Visual progress can boost team morale by showing tangible progress toward goals.  By leveraging burnup charts in Zymmr, teams can maintain better control over their projects, ensure timely deliveries, and adjust plans proactively based on visual insights.

searchDocs.title: Windows​
searchDocs.content: Install Docker Desktop: If you haven't already, you need to install Docker Desktop on your Windows machine. Docker Desktop provides an easy-to-use interface for managing Docker containers and images on Windows. You can download it from the official Docker website and follow the installation instructions. Clone this repo or download the compose file: This file will define the configuration for your Docker containers, including the environment variables, services, networks, and volumes. Open Command Prompt or PowerShell: Open Command Prompt or PowerShell on your Windows machine. Navigate to Project Directory: Use the cd command to navigate to the directory where your docker-compose.yml file is located. Run Docker Compose Command: Once you're in the correct directory, you can run the following command to start the containers defined in your docker-compose.yml file: set SITE_NAME=abc.zymmr.com && docker-compose up -d This command sets the SITE_NAME environment variable to abc.zymmr.com and then starts the Docker containers defined in the docker-compose.yml file in detached mode (-d flag). Once the containers are up and running, you can verify that everything is working as expected. You can access Zymmmr by opening a web browser and navigating to http://<server-ip>

searchDocs.title: Linux​
searchDocs.content: Install Docker Engine: If you haven't already, you need to install Docker Engine on your Linux machine. Docker Engine provides a platform to develop, ship, and run containers. You can install it by following the official Docker documentation for your specific Linux distribution. Clone this repo or download the compose file: This file will define the configuration for your Docker containers, including the environment variables, services, networks, and volumes. Open Terminal: Open a terminal on your Linux machine. Navigate to Project Directory: Use the cd command to navigate to the directory where your docker-compose.yml file is located. Run Docker Compose Command: Once you're in the correct directory, you can run the following command to start the containers defined in your docker-compose.yml file: SITE_NAME=abc.zymmr.com && docker-compose up -d This command sets the SITE_NAME environment variable to abc.zymmr.com and then starts the Docker containers defined in the docker-compose.yml file in detached mode (-d flag). Once the containers are up and running, you can verify that everything is working as expected. You can access your Zymmr by opening a web browser and navigating to http://<server-ip>

searchDocs.title: What is a Release?​
searchDocs.content: A release in Zymmr is a specific version or segment of a project that is delivered to stakeholders. Releases help manage and track project deliverables, ensuring each version is documented and delivered on schedule.

searchDocs.title: How to Create a Release in Zymmr​
Navigate to Project Listing Page​
searchDocs.content: From the Projects listing, search for the project you want to configure.Click on the project to open it.On the right side, click on the 'Project Configuration Settings' icon.

searchDocs.title: Access the Releases Section​
searchDocs.content: In the configuration settings, look for the Releases section.Click on the Releases section to open it.

searchDocs.title: Create a Release​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Create Release' icon.Fill in the following details: Release Name: Enter a descriptive name for the release.Start Date: Define the start date of the release.End Date: Define the end date of the release.Description: Provide a detailed description of the release. Click the 'Save' button to save the details.Once saved, all releases are listed.

searchDocs.title: View and Manage Releases​
searchDocs.content: All releases for the project will be listed with the following information:  Release NameStart DateEnd DateStatus: Shows if the release is unreleased or has been released.

searchDocs.title: Options available for each release include:​
searchDocs.content: Release: Release this changing the status to ‘Released’ Archive: Archive the release. Edit: Edit the release details. Delete: Delete the release. Note: All releases are considered unreleased until the status is changed to "Released." The release listing also includes a search function to find specific releases. Note: If a work item is associated with a release, the release cannot be deleted. An error message will indicate this restriction.

searchDocs.title: How to Search and Edit a Release​
Search for a Release​
searchDocs.content: Use the search function in the Releases section to find the release you want to edit.

searchDocs.title: Edit Release Details​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Edit' icon in the options next to the release you want to modify.Update the necessary details such as Release Name, Start Date, End Date, and Description.Click 'Save' to apply the changes.

searchDocs.title: Search for the Release​
searchDocs.content: Use the search function in the Releases section to find the release you wish to delete.

searchDocs.title: Delete the Release​
searchDocs.content: Click on the 'Delete' icon next to the release.Confirm the deletion when prompted. Note: If a work item is associated with a release, the release cannot be deleted. An error message will indicate this restriction.

searchDocs.title: Important Note​
searchDocs.content: Releases will remain in the "unreleased" state until the status is explicitly changed to "released," impacting the project's tracking and reporting.

searchDocs.title: Key Functionalities​
searchDocs.content: Filtering by Project: Choose specific projects or multiple projects to include in the Gantt chart.By default, the system uses a creation date filter of 60 days. View Options: Day View: Displays tasks on a daily basis.Week View: Displays tasks on a weekly basis.Month View: Displays tasks on a monthly basis.Release View: Provides an overview of tasks related to specific releases. Task Display: Work items are shown with their start and end dates.Overdue tasks are depicted in red. Task Relationships: Relationships between tasks (dependencies) are visually represented. Color Customization: Gantt colors can be customized under the Gantt Customization section in Settings.Different colors are used to indicate the status of tasks: CompletedCompleted LateIn ProgressOverdue

searchDocs.title: Example Use Case​
searchDocs.content: Scenario: You need to review the timeline and dependencies of tasks for the "Mobile App Development" project. Steps: Filter by Project: Select the "Mobile App Development" project.Choose View: Opt for the "Month View" to get a broader overview of the project's progress.Review Task Display: Check the start and end dates of tasks, noting any that are overdue (highlighted in red).Analyze Task Relationships: Look at the dependencies between tasks to understand how delays might impact the project.Customize Colors: If necessary, adjust the color settings under Gantt Customization in Settings to better visualize different task statuses.  By utilizing the Gantt feature, you can efficiently monitor project timelines, understand task dependencies, and identify any delays or issues that need to be addressed to keep the project on track.

searchDocs.title: Data Imports
searchDocs.content: Data Imports

searchDocs.title: Key Features of Zymmr Burndown Charts​
Choice of Metrics​
searchDocs.content: Story Points: Ideal for teams estimating work in story points.Effort: Suitable for teams tracking progress in hours or days.

searchDocs.title: Three Key Lines​
searchDocs.content: Guideline: A reference line representing the ideal progress needed to complete the project on time.Work Remaining Line: Shows the actual amount of work left to be completed.Extrapolation Line: Projects future progress based on current trends. This can be toggled on or off.

searchDocs.title: How to Access and Use Burndown Charts in Zymmr​
Accessing the Burndown Chart​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Projects tab.Select the specific project you want to track.In the project's menu, located to the left of the backlog page, click on the Burndown Chart option.

searchDocs.title: Configuring the Chart​
searchDocs.content: Choose whether to display the chart in story points or effort.Toggle the extrapolation line on or off based on your preference.

searchDocs.title: Interpreting the Lines​
searchDocs.content: Guideline: This line represents the ideal rate at which work should be completed to finish the project on schedule.Work Remaining Line: This line shows the actual amount of work left to be completed, updated regularly as tasks are finished.Extrapolation Line: When turned on, this line projects future progress based on current trends, helping you predict if the project will stay on track.

searchDocs.title: Adjusting and Analyzing​
searchDocs.content: Filter the chart by specific criteria, such as sprints.Use the chart to identify trends, potential delays, or areas where scope changes are impacting progress.

searchDocs.title: Benefits of Using Burndown Charts​
searchDocs.content: Transparency: Provides clear visibility into how much work remains and the pace at which work is being completed.Forecasting: Helps predict if the project will be completed on time by comparing the work remaining to the guideline and extrapolation lines.Scope Management: Easily identify and manage changes in project scope and their impact on the project timeline.Motivation: Visual progress can boost team morale by showing tangible progress towards goals.  By leveraging burndown charts in Zymmr, teams can maintain better control over their projects, ensure timely deliveries, and adjust plans proactively based on visual insights.

searchDocs.title: Comment on Workitem
searchDocs.content: Comment on Workitem

searchDocs.title: Deleting a Work Item in Zymmr
Steps to Delete a Work Item​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Deleting a Work Item in Zymmr

searchDocs.title: 1. Access the Work Item​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Deleting a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Navigate to either the Backlog or the Work Items page.Choose the work item you want to delete.

searchDocs.title: 2. Open Work Item Details​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Deleting a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Click on the key of the work item to open the detailed work item page.

searchDocs.title: 3. Initiate Deletion​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Deleting a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: On the work item detail page, click on the three dots (more options).Select the Delete option from the dropdown menu.

searchDocs.title: 4. Confirm Deletion​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Deleting a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: A confirmation dialog will appear: "Are you sure you want to permanently delete [work item]?"Confirm the deletion.

searchDocs.title: 5. Relationship Check​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Deleting a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: If the work item has relationships with other items, the system will throw an error and will not delete the item.  This process ensures that you can safely delete work items that are not dependent on other items, maintaining the integrity of your project data.

searchDocs.title: WorkItem in Zymmr: A Comprehensive Guide
Key Attributes of WorkItem​
searchDocs.pageTitle: WorkItem in Zymmr: A Comprehensive Guide
searchDocs.content: Title: A concise label for the WorkItem that succinctly conveys its purpose. Description: A detailed narrative outlining the scope, objectives, and requirements of the WorkItem. WorkItem Key: A unique identifier assigned to each individual WorkItem. Project Name: A unique and descriptive title for the specific project. WorkItem Type: Categorization or classification of a work item, such as tasks, bugs, or user stories. WorkItem Priority: Relative importance or urgency assigned to a specific task within a project. WorkItem Status: Current state or condition of a specific task, indicating whether it's complete, in progress, or facing challenges. Primary Assignee: The person primarily responsible for completing a specific WorkItem. Secondary Assignee: An individual providing additional support or assistance for a specific WorkItem. Reporter: The person who raises or creates a WorkItem within Zymmr. Story Points: A unit of measurement used in Agile methodologies to estimate the effort and complexity of tasks. Estimate Effort: Expected amount of time required to complete a specific WorkItem. Logged Time: Actual time spent working on a specific WorkItem. Remaining Time: Time needed to complete a task based on the initial estimate and logged time. Auto Estimate: Machine learning feature predicting and assigning estimated effort or time to WorkItem. Start Date: Planned date when the task is scheduled to begin. End Date: Planned date when the task is expected to complete. Watchers: Individuals interested in staying updated about the progress and changes related to a specific issue. Tags: Labels or keywords associated with WorkItems for categorization and organization. Parent WorkItem: Higher-level task or issue that encompasses related sub-tasks or child issues. Affects Versions: Indicates which versions or releases of a product are impacted by a specific issue. Fix Version: Indicates in which version or release an issue has been resolved or fixed. Modules: Labels or categories used to group and categorize WorkItems within a project. Milestone: Significant event or achievement marking a specific point in a project's timeline. Comments: Text-based messages or notes added to issues for communication and collaboration. Attachments: Files, documents, or images associated with a specific WorkItem. Related Task: Establishes relationships or connections between different WorkItems within a project. Activity Log: Records all activities, changes, and events throughout the lifecycle of a WorkItem. Time Log: Recording the time spent on specific WorkItems within a project. Sprint: Represents the Agile concept of a fixed time period during which a team works on a set of tasks. Dev Tab: Provides insights into the technical development and coding aspects of a WorkItem. Bitbucket Integration: Seamless workflow for tracking and managing development activities, code changes, and project progress.

searchDocs.title: Log Time
searchDocs.content: Log Time

searchDocs.title: Link Workitems
searchDocs.content: Link Workitems

searchDocs.title: Search Workitem with Filters
searchDocs.content: Search Workitem with Filters

searchDocs.title: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
Accessing the Work Item​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Backlog or Work Items page.Select the work item you want to edit.

searchDocs.title: Editable Fields​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Type: Change the type of the work item.Priority: Update the priority level.Status: Modify the current status.Title: Change the title of the work item.Description: Update the description as needed.Tags: Add or update tags associated with the work item.Affect Release: Change the affected release version.Fixed Release: Update the fixed release version.Modules: Add or change associated modules.Milestones: Add or update milestones linked to the work item.

searchDocs.title: People​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Primary Assignee: Assign the main person responsible.Secondary Assignee: Assign additional responsible person.Reporter: Automatically set to the person who creates the work item.

searchDocs.title: Estimates​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Story Point: Editable field for effort estimation.Estimated Effort: Editable field for estimated time in format (e.g., 6h 45m).Logged Time: System-collated based on time logs.Remaining Time: System-collated based on estimated effort and logged time.Auto Estimate: Smart field system-generated estimate based on title and assignee.

searchDocs.title: Timeline​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Start Date: Editable start date.End Date: Editable end date.Actual Start Date: System updated based on change of state.Completion Date: System generated based on end date.

searchDocs.title: Watchers​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Add or remove watchers based on team members.

searchDocs.title: Work Item Detail Page​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Comments: Team members can add comments with @mentions.Attachments: Upload or remove attachments.Related Tasks: Add sub-tasks and related tasks. Opens a dialog to specify link types such as Blocker, Blocked, Clones, and select work item.Activity Logs: System-generated logs tracking all actions taken on the work item.Timelog: Log time and see details of logged time.Sprint: Change sprint and see details of sprint changes.Smart Commit: Perform smart commits for the work item.

searchDocs.title: Save Changes​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Updating/Editing a Work Item in Zymmr
searchDocs.content: Ensure all updates are complete.Save the changes to apply updates to the work item.  This comprehensive guide helps in managing and updating work items in Zymmr, ensuring accurate and up-to-date project information.

searchDocs.title: How to create a project category​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Global Settings icon ⚙️ > Project Category.Click on Create Category.Name your category and Save.  See How

searchDocs.title: How to assign a project category​
searchDocs.content: Search for your project and click Project settings link 🔗.From the sidebar, select Details.Click on EditSelect a project category and click Save project.  See How   note You can also assign project category while creating new project.

searchDocs.title: How to delete a project category​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Global Settings icon > Project Category.Search for category you want to deleteclick on delete icon and confirm.  See How   warning You are not allowed to delete category if its assigned on any project,To delete you need to either re-assign or remove category from project

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: The Zymmr Dashboard is a static dashboard that provides a snapshot of key information relevant to the logged-in user. It helps users quickly access their projects, track performance, and manage tasks.

searchDocs.title: Dashboard Features​
searchDocs.content: My Projects: Displays a list of projects assigned to the user. Performance in the Last Three Months: Shows performance metrics and trends over the past three months. Assigned to Me: Lists work items that are currently assigned to the user. Overdue: Displays work items that are overdue. The number of days overdue is shown in red for easy identification. In Progress: Lists work items that are currently in progress.  Note Each section has a Show More link if the number of work items under any category exceeds 5. This link provides a detailed listing for that category.Clicking on the Work Item Key in any section brings up the detailed work item view.Overdue items are highlighted with the number of days overdue in red, making it easy to prioritize and address them.

searchDocs.title: Setup Workflow schemes
searchDocs.content: Setup Workflow schemes

searchDocs.title: User Management
searchDocs.content: User Management

searchDocs.title: Access the Login Page​
searchDocs.content: Open your web browser and navigate to the Zymmr login page.

searchDocs.title: Enter Credentials​
searchDocs.content: Organizational ID: Enter your assigned organizational ID.Password: Enter your password.Show Password: If you need to verify your password as you type, click the Show Password option.

searchDocs.title: Click Login​
searchDocs.content: After entering your credentials, click the Login button to access your Zymmr account.  Note Ensure that your organizational ID and password are correct to avoid login issues.If you forget your password, use the Forgot Password link on the login page to reset it.

searchDocs.title: Related Documentation​
searchDocs.content: Create User: For information on how to create a new user in Zymmr, refer to the Create User section under the settings of Zymmr. This documentation provides detailed steps on setting up user accounts, which is essential for administrators and managers.

searchDocs.title: Create an Issue Type Scheme:​
searchDocs.content: Navigate to the Administration section in Zymmr.Find and select the "Work Item Type Schemes" option.Create a new scheme named "Software Project Types" or a relevant title.

searchDocs.title: Define Work Item Types:​
searchDocs.content: Add the necessary issue types for your software project. In this example, include: BugFeature  Check how to create new work item here

searchDocs.title: Configure the Work Item Type Scheme:​
searchDocs.content: Associate the created issue types with the scheme. Bug -> BugFeature -> Feature

searchDocs.title: Set Default Issue Type:​
searchDocs.content: Choose a default issue type for your scheme. For instance, set "Bug" as the default type.

searchDocs.title: Apply the Scheme to Projects:​
searchDocs.content: Once configured, apply the "Software Project Types" scheme to relevant software projects.This ensures that these projects share a standardized set of issue types.  By implementing this work item type scheme, your team can easily select appropriate issue types when creating new items. It also ensures consistency across projects, making it more straightforward to manage and maintain your projects within Zymmr.

searchDocs.title: Default Issue Types​
searchDocs.content: Here's a list of the default work item types that come with each Zymmer project:

searchDocs.title: Epic​
searchDocs.content: An Epic is like a big story for your project that's too large to handle all at once. It's made up of bugs, stories, and tasks, showing how things are progressing with a major project. In agile development, epics usually stand for something big, like a cool new feature or experience in the software your team is building.

searchDocs.title: Bug​
searchDocs.content: A bug is a problem that messes up or stops a product from working properly.

searchDocs.title: Story​
searchDocs.content: A user story is the smallest piece of work that needs to get done.

searchDocs.title: Task​
searchDocs.content: A task is a job that needs to be finished.

searchDocs.title: Subtask​
searchDocs.content: A subtask is a small piece of work needed to finish a task. Subtasks can break down any regular jobs in Zymmr, like bugs, stories, or tasks.  Each project in Zymmer comes with default work item types carefully crafted to meet the diverse needs of your projects and teams. Yet, we understand that one size doesn't fit all. That's why Zymmr allows you to tailor your work item types to align seamlessly with your preferred project management process.

searchDocs.title: Using WorkItem in Project​
searchDocs.content: note You need to be Global Admin or Account admin to Manage workitems
